The Site manufactures frozen appetizers. The Site's North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 311412 (Frozen Specialty Food Manufacturing)



As part of the refrigeration system to freeze the appetizers, the Site handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical, as defined in the USEPA's CAPP and OSHA's PSM standard, in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold for anhydrous ammonia in a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. The Site is registered to Program Level 3 under the CAPP program.



The anhydrous ammonia is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system. The Site's engine room houses the majority of the refrigeration machinery.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION



While there are few long-term environmental consequences to ammonia use, it can present health hazards if handled improperly. RPC has developed a comprehensive safety program in compliance with OSHA and EPA requirements to ensure the responsible management of the ammonia onsite (the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program, respectively). All refrigeration Associates receive operator training, safe work practices training and training on the standard operating procedures (SOPs). Safety meetings are conducted to further protect Associates and the community as a whole.



The Site's prevention program is designed to inform all Associates of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates and the community in the event of a release or spill.



The Site endeavors to eliminate accidents and health hazards to Associates, customers, and the community by having procedures in place to provide Associates educational training, safe working conditions, an

d the means to increase awareness of potential dangers both on and off the job. In addition to the ongoing inspection and maintenance of the refrigeration system, wherever possible refrigeration system components are located in areas that are not as likely to become damaged (i.e., tanks and pipe runs are placed away and protected from forklift and truck traffic). RPC's objective is to prevent unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could potentially expose Associates and others to serious hazards. An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire system. Workplace and process safety are major concerns to management and Associates alike. The prevention and mitigation of unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could expose Associates and the community to serious hazards is of primary concern.



The Site has incorporated many safety features in the design of the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Site's ammonia system is continuously monitored by automated control systems that shutdown pump and the components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the system is equipped with pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels and most, if not all, additional locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped.



RPC considers the health and safety of each Associate as its most important responsibility. It is our policy to provide a healthy and safe work environment. This facility follows operating practices that safeguard all associates and result in safe working conditions while maintaining efficient operations.



Safety is the responsibility of all Associates. Each associate is expected to comply with the requirements of RPC's Standards for Saf

ety Performance. Management is responsible for the implementation, communication, documentation, and necessary training. The Associate is responsible for implementation, communication, and practices of the program. Management is committed to maintain a high level of interest in health and safety throughout this facility. This commitment extends to the associates and their involvement in preventing accidents.



RPC has established its Health and Safety Program to insure that:



-- Associates work in a healthy and safe environment.

-- Associates are trained on safe work practices.

-- Associates practice safe work habits.

-- Management and associates are both involved in the program.

-- There is constant communication between all Associates on safety issues.

-- Compliance with all regulatory agencies is maintained.



Major safety features at the Site include:



-- Installation of ammonia leak detectors in processing areas and the engine room;

-- Remote emergency shutdown switches for the refrigeration system;

-- Fire sprinklers throughout the Site;

-- Component specific safety shutdowns of the refrigeration system, and

-- A proprietary Refrigeration Energy Management System (REMS) computer monitoring system.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Within the previous five (5) years, there have been no accidental releases.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Site is equipped with an emergency warning system. Alarms are placed throughout the Site to alarm personnel of an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia or other emergencies that may be encountered. RPC has developed specific procedures to be followed in the event of release. These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so. Security personnel are on site 24 hours, 7 days per week.



Plant personnel have received emergency response training as outlined in OSHA's HAZWOPER regulati

on (29 CFR 1910.120) and other various rules and regulations.



Site Associates have coordinated the Site's emergency response program with the Glynn County and Brunswick Fire Departments.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Site recognizes that the implementation of this program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operation at the Site. As such, the prevention program will evolve as RPC continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for the employees and the surrounding community.

 

RPC FRESNO



Rich Products Corporation - Fresno (RPC-FNO) has developed this program in accordance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA's) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (CAPP) of the Clean Air Act, as amended (CAAA), a.k.a., the Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule, which is codified at 40 CFR 68; the United States Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (HHCs) standard (PSM standard), which is codified at 29 CFR 1910.119; California OSHA's (Cal/OSHA's) PSM standard, which is codified at Section 5189 of Title 8 of the California Code of Regulations (CCR)(8 CCR 5189), and the the California Office of Emergency Services' (CalOES') California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program, which is codified at 19 CCR 2-4.5. The program is designed to inform all Site employees (hereafter referred to as Associates) of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates in the event of a release or spill (i.e., emergency response plan, management of change procedures, preventative maintenance program, associate training, etc.).

Be the Trusted First Choice - Listen, understand and deliver for customers like no other company;

RPC is committed to an irrevocable obligation to act responsibly in every decision made and with every person encountered. RPC understands it is a trusted steward of its business relationships, its environment and the communities in which it serves. RPC holds itself to the highest set of standards and is about doing what's right...no matter what.





FACILITY DESCRIPTION



RPC-FNO, a.k.a., the Site, is located at 320 O Street in the City of Fresno, Fresno County, California and is situated in a heavy industrial portion of the downtown area. The Site occupies an approximately 85,000-square-foot structure that includes office, laboratory, manufacturing, maintenance shop, and warehouse space. The Site was built in early 1900 and several additions have been made since then. The Site operates normally 5 to 7 days per week, 24 hours per day.



The Site produces doughs, which are frozen for shipment . The Site's North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 31199 (All Other Food Manufacturing)



As part of the refrigeration system to freeze the doughs for shipment, the Site handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical, as defined in the USEPA's CAPP, Cal/OSHA's and OSHA's PSM standard, and CalOES' CalARP program in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold for anhydrous ammonia in a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. RPC-FNO operates two anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems that are interconnected and subsequently are categorized as a single process. The Site is registered to Program Level 3 under both the CAPP and CalARP programs.



The anhydrous ammonia is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system.

The Site's engine rooms house the majority of the refrigeration machinery.
